timeline.message:
Added metrics property to the cruiseControl in Kafka resource
Added CO logic for enabling the CC metrics

Signed-off-by: Paolo Patierno <ppatierno@live.com>

Added Kafka example with Cruise Control with metrics enabled
Added Cruise Control related Grafana dashboard

Signed-off-by: Paolo Patierno <ppatierno@live.com>

timeline.bodyText: Can we get some better descriptions? For example I have no idea what does Balancedness Score, which value is good, which bad etc. ... I guess 100 is bad here since it is orange in the screenshot?
timeline.author: scholzj

replies.bodyText: Yes, I reverted the logic in the dashboard, now higher values are green while lower are orange and then red. I used 50 (for red) and 80 (orange) as thresholds.
replies.author: ppatierno

replies.bodyText:
So is 100 a maximum? TBH, I think the Cruise Control is relative niche ... so the descriptions are IMHO quite important since many people will be looking at it as I'm ... without having a clue.
BTW: Should we have a sample alert for this as well?
replies.author: scholzj

replies.bodyText:
Yes 100 is the max.
Regarding the alerts I would add them in a different PR as already did for the bridge metrics.
replies.author: ppatierno

replies.bodyText: I think it is useful to have this metric as a one-stop-shop for quickly checking the state of the cluster. To be clear this is the current balancedness score of the cluster as calculated by the anomaly detector (using KafkaCruiseControlUtils.balancednessCostByGoal CC method) and isupdated every 5 mins by default (can be changed by setting anomaly.detection.interval.ms). I wonder if we need some docs to describe how this is calculated and what it means?
replies.author: tomncooper

replies.bodyText: So can we add this stuff to the description?
replies.author: scholzj

timeline.bodyText: What does valid window mean?
timeline.author: scholzj

replies.bodyText: It should be a time window where there are enough samples for computing a proposal, but I am sure @tomncooper can say more.
replies.author: ppatierno

replies.bodyText: Each window has a number of samples after which it is considered "valid". The user can also configure how many windows CC should hold onto. Details here
replies.author: tomncooper

replies.bodyText: So can we add it to the description?

replies.bodyText: So as far as I understood from the DiskFailureDetector code, it periodically tries to get info on the log dirs on the brokers (using the Admin Client API describeLogDirs) and the callback is able to provide info about errors which are potential disk failures.
replies.author: ppatierno

replies.bodyText: I think this is a bit scary then ... what about calling it Failed disk queries or something like that?
replies.author: scholzj

replies.bodyText: Maybe "disk read failure rate"?
replies.author: ppatierno

replies.bodyText: TBH, I think Failed disk queries would be better because IMHO it makes it more clear that this is just about Cruise Control issue when querying the disk. Disk read failure rate can still be easily confused with a physical disk issue. But I can live with it if needed.
replies.author: scholzj

replies.bodyText: I see your point you want to highlight that it's something more related to CC than the disk itself even if when CC has a "query" failure, it could mean a real disk failure. @tomncooper any opinion on this?
replies.author: ppatierno

replies.bodyText: So the disk failures are detected using the code here. It seems to use the Kafka Admin client to ask for broker status and then checks for reported errors in each of the log directories.
replies.author: tomncooper

replies.bodyText: That was the code I was referring to (without linking the code actually). But what's a good name/description for you?
replies.author: ppatierno

replies.bodyText: Sorry @ppatierno I didn't read your comment at the top and basically repeated exactly what you said. Not very helpful. Anyway this metric is the number of disc failures in the last detection interval (which will be the same as the AD interval unless the user specifies a different interval for the disk failure detection), so it is a "rate" and it is a failure according to Kafka. So something like "Disk Failure Rate", "Reported Disk Failure Rate" or "Kafka Reported Disk Failure Rate" seems accurate to me.
replies.author: tomncooper

timeline.bodyText: Is this number of executed partition movemenets per second or something like that?
timeline.author: scholzj

timeline.author: tomncooper
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,69 @@
+// This assembly is included in the following assemblies:
+//
+// metrics/assembly-metrics.adoc
+
+[id='assembly-cruise-control-{context}']
+= Monitor Cruise Control
+
+If you are already using Prometheus and Grafana for monitoring of built-in Kafka metrics, you can configure Prometheus to also scrape the Cruise Control Prometheus endpoint.
+
+The example Grafana dashboard for the Cruise Control provides:
+
+* Information about rebalance proposals computation, goals violation, cluster balancedness and more
+* Information about REST API calls for rebalance proposals and actual rebalance operations
+* JVM metrics from Cruise Control itself
+
+== Configuring Cruise Control
+
+You can enable the Cruise Control metrics in the `Kafka` resource using the `cruiseControl.metrics` property that contains the JMX exporter configuration about metrics to expose.
+
+For example:
++
+[source,yaml,subs="attributes+"]
+----
+apiVersion: {KafkaApiVersion}
+kind: Kafka
+metadata:
+  name: my-cluster
+spec:
+  # ...
+  kafka:
+    # ...
+  zookeeper:
+    # ...
+  cruiseControl:
+    metrics:
+      lowercaseOutputName: true
+      rules:
+      - pattern: kafka.cruisecontrol<name=(.+)><>(\w+)
+        name: kafka_cruisecontrol_$1_$2
+        type: GAUGE
+----
+
+== Enabling the Cruise Control Grafana dashboard
+
+If you deployed Cruise Control with your Kafka cluster with the metrics enabled, you can enable Grafana to present the metrics data it exposes.
+
+A Cruise Control dashboard is provided in the `examples/metrics` directory as a JSON file:
+
+* `strimzi-cruise-control.json`
+
+When metrics data has been collected for some time, the Cruise Control charts are populated.
+
+Cruise Control:: Shows metrics for:
++
+* The number of snapshot windows that are monitored
+* Number of time windows considered to be valid because of enough samples for computing a proposal.

+// This assembly is included in the following assemblies:

+[id='assembly-cruise-control-{context}']
+= Monitor Cruise Control
+
+If you are already using Prometheus and Grafana for monitoring of built-in Kafka metrics, you can configure Prometheus to also scrape the Cruise Control Prometheus endpoint.
+
+The example Grafana dashboard for the Cruise Control provides:
+
+* Information about optimization proposals computation, goals violation, cluster balancedness and more
+* Information about REST API calls for rebalance proposals and actual rebalance operations
+* JVM metrics from Cruise Control itself
+
+== Configuring Cruise Control
+
+You can enable the Cruise Control metrics in the `Kafka` resource using the `cruiseControl.metrics` property that contains the JMX exporter configuration about metrics to expose.
+
+For example:
++
+[source,yaml,subs="attributes+"]
+----
+apiVersion: {KafkaApiVersion}
+kind: Kafka
+metadata:
+  name: my-cluster
+spec:
+  # ...
+  kafka:
+    # ...
+  zookeeper:
+    # ...
+  cruiseControl:
+    metrics:
+      lowercaseOutputName: true
+      rules:
+      - pattern: kafka.cruisecontrol<name=(.+)><>(\w+)
+        name: kafka_cruisecontrol_$1_$2
+        type: GAUGE
+----
+
+== Enabling the Cruise Control Grafana dashboard
+
+If you deployed Cruise Control with your Kafka cluster with the metrics enabled, you can enable Grafana to present the metrics data it exposes.
+

+
+When metrics data has been collected for some time, the Cruise Control charts are populated.

+* The number of snapshot windows that are monitored
+* Number of time windows considered to be valid because of enough samples for computing a proposal
+* Number of ongoing executions running for proposals or rebalances
+* The current balancedness score of the Kafka cluster as calculated by the anomaly detector (every 5 minutes by default)
